title: Why Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain missed Liverpool’s dramatic win over Leicester City
text:
Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain was left off the team sheet for Liverpool’s clash with Leicester (Picture: Getty)

Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain might not have been expecting to start for Liverpool against Leicester but the midfielder would have expected to be part of the 18 players named on the team sheet.

However, the England international did not feature in the starting XI or as a substitute leaving Reds fans baffled as he had not previously been listed as injured.

But Oxlade-Chamberlain is understood to have suffered an injury during training yesterday that has seen Liverpool leave him out as a precaution.

The injury itself came about when the former Southampton and Arsenal player was struck on the head by a football – and he was still feeling the after-effects of a mild concussion earlier today.

Oxlade-Chamberlain missed the majority of last season after suffering a serious knee injury during the Champions League semi-final in the 2017/18 season.

After nearly a year of rehabilitation, the 26-year-old is now back in contention for a first-team place but has still only started twice in the Premier League this season.

He even featured in Gareth Southgate’s England squad last month but was then left out because, according to the national team boss, he had failed to win more minutes in Klopp’s side.

‘I had a chat with him this morning, last month we brought him back earlier,’ Southgate said when he announced his squad earlier this week.

‘We wanted him to know he has been part of our thoughts and give him a boost – only had a few games since then. Like Dele [Alli], season hasn’t got going yet.’

Oxlade-Chamberlain has only just worked his way back to full fitness (Picture: Getty)

Liverpool, as it turned out, did not need Oxlade-Chamberlain’s spark in midfield as beat Leicester in stoppage time to maintain their 100 per cent record in the Premier League.

Sadio Mane had given the Reds the lead in the first half after a through-ball from James Milner but they were pegged back after the break by James Maddison, whose shot found a way past Adrian.

Virgil van Dijk had the chance to win it for Liverpool but headed over the bar only for a clumsy challenge on Mane to give Milner the chance to score from the spot and give the Reds all three points.
